Title: Copolymerization of acenaphthylene with methacrylic monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of acenaphthylene with methylmethacrylate, ethylmethacrylate, butylmethacrylete, iso-butylmethacrylate and cyclohexylmethacrylate has been carried out in tetrahydrofuran at 323 K and the composition of the copolymers has been determined by size exclusion chromatography using a double RI-UV detector system. Several methods have been applied to obtain the reactivity ratios of the copolymerization process. The glass transition temperature of the copolymers has been obtained by DSC and the thermal stability has been studied by thermogravimetry. Analysis of the degradation volatile products reveals that copolymers degrade mainly by depolymerization.</jats:p>

Title: Formation of crosslinked polymers in the copolymerization of 9,10‐anthrylenedimethyl dimethacrylate and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The formation of a crosslinked polymer during the copolymerization of mono‐and bifunctional monomers was investigated choosing as an example the free‐radical copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (MMA) and 9,10‐anthrylenedimethyl dimethacrylate (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>). The anthracenecontaining crosslinks permit the determination of the topological structure of soluble MMA‐1 copolymers containing bridge bonds. This copolymer is formed first and characterized by a considerable structural heterogeneity. The intrinsic viscosity of the soluble copolymer increases sharply in a certain reaction stage and, at the same time, an insoluble copolymer fraction appears. In the formation of the gel fraction those branched macromolecules which consist of a greater number of linear components and contain a greater number of “pendent” double bonds participate first.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate with alkyl acrylates
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Reactivity ratios for acrylonitrile–vinyl chloroacetate copolymerization systems
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Reactivity ratios for acrylonitrile—vinyl chloroacetate systems have been determined for radical copolymerization at 60°C in dimethylformamide. The values of the ratios calculated by the linear graphical method of Kelen and Tüdös were as follows: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 4.05 ± 0.1 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.001 ± 0.001 for acrylonitrile (AN)—vinyl monochloroacetate (VCAc), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 7.0 ± 0.25 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.05 ± 0.015 for acrylonitrile—vinyl dichloroacetate (VDAc), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 7.13 ± 0.25 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.06 ± 0.015 for acrylonitrile—vinyl trichloroacetate (VTAc). The penultimate model of the copolymerization and the effect of the vinyl chloroacetate structure were discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios for acrylonitrile–vinyl chloroacetate copolymerization systems
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Reactivity ratios for acrylonitrile—vinyl chloroacetate systems have been determined for radical copolymerization at 60°C in dimethylformamide. The values of the ratios calculated by the linear graphical method of Kelen and Tüdös were as follows: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 4.05 ± 0.1 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.001 ± 0.001 for acrylonitrile (AN)—vinyl monochloroacetate (VCAc), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 7.0 ± 0.25 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.05 ± 0.015 for acrylonitrile—vinyl dichloroacetate (VDAc), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 7.13 ± 0.25 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.06 ± 0.015 for acrylonitrile—vinyl trichloroacetate (VTAc). The penultimate model of the copolymerization and the effect of the vinyl chloroacetate structure were discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Modeling of the copolymerization, with depropagation, of α‐methyl styrene and methyl methacrylate at an elevated temperature
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a dynamic model for the copolymerization of α‐methyl styrene (α‐MS) and methyl methacrylate (MMA) in a batch reactor. The parameters are based on data from the literature and our own laboratories over the full conversion range. A two‐parameter model with constant reactivity ratios shows the most reasonable results. The dynamic model depicts the reaction kinetics and reactor behavior more clearly. Termination occurs mainly by the cross reaction of unlike radicals, and its rate increases with the molar ratio of α‐MS to MMA. The model enables us to predict the instantaneous and cumulative properties of the copolymer and also provides us with a basic tool for the optimization and control of industrial reactors. © 2004 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 93: 261–270, 2004</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity of vinyl ketones in free radical copolymerization with methyl methacrylate and vinyl acetate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity of some monomer vinyl ketones in the radical copolymerization with methyl methacrylate and vinyl acetate was studied on the basis of the Taft equation. It was concluded that the relative reactivities of the vinyl ketones in radical reactions increase with increasing electron‐withdrawing nature of the vinyl ketone substituent. Polar and steric effects do not affect the reactivity.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios in copolymerization: a new method to determine r1 when r2 = 0
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of cationic monomers with acrylamide in an aqueous solution
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerizations of commercially available cationic monomers (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with acrylamide (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) have been investigated at pH 6.1 in aqueous solutions. The cationic groups in copolymers were analyzed by a colloid titration method and the reactivity ratios were determined by the Fineman–Ross method. The values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were 1.71 and 0.25 for methacryloyloxyethyltrimethylammonium chlorideM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 1.68 and 1.26 for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylaminoethylmethacrylateM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 1.13 and 0.57 for methacrylamidopropyltrimethylammonium chlorideM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 1.10 and 0.47 for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylaminopropylmethacrylateM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 0.47 and 0.95 for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylaminopropylacrylamideM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 0.48 and 0.64 for acryloyloxyethyltrimethylammonium chloride‐M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, and 0.58 and 6.7 for dimethyldiallylammonium chloride‐M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> systems. The Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were calculated and the linear relationship between log <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and ultraviolet absorption maxima of cationic monomers was found.</jats:p>

Title: Dispersion copolymerization of methyl methacrylate and n‐butyl acrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In the dispersion copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (MMA) and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate (BA), the particle size increases with an increasing MMA fraction in the comonomer. The power dependence of the particle size on the initiator concentration also increases with an increasing MMA concentration. Similar to what can be found in the homopolymerizations, two populations can be observed in the molecular weight distributions of the copolymers. Core–shell structured particles with a poly(methyl methacrylate)‐rich core and a poly(<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate)‐rich shell result from the copolymerizations because of the significantly different reactivity ratios. The reaction rates of the dispersion copolymerization are lower than those of the homopolymerization of BA and close to or lower than those of the homopolymerization of MMA, depending on the ratio of the monomers. © 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 45: 2105–2112, 2007</jats:p>

Title: On the preparation of acrylic acid/vinyl acetate copolymers with constant composition — 1. Copolymerization reactivity ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of alkyl α‐chloroacrylates with methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Hexyl α‐chloroacrylate (HCA) and cyclohexyl α‐chloroacrylate (CCA) have been copolymerized with methyl methacrylate (MMA) in toluene at 55°C using azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator. Copolymer compositions have been determined both by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR and elemental analyses. For copolymerization of MMA (M1) with HCA (M2), the reactivity ratios (RR) are r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.47 ± 0.19 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.81 ± 0.51 and with CCA the values are r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.76 ± 0.31 and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2.30 ± 1.73. Thermal properties of these copolymers have also been investigated.</jats:p>

Title: Homo- and copolymerization of N-(2-thiazolyl)methacrylamide with different vinyl monomers: Synthesis, characterization, determination of monomer reactivity ratios and biological activity
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Kinetic study by differential scanning calorimetry of the bulk copolymerization of 2‐hydroxyethylmethacrylate with ethyleneglycoldimethacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This article presents a kinetic study of the copolymerization of 2‐hydroxyethylmethacrylate (HEMA) with ethyleneglycoldimethacrylate (EGDMA). First, the rate constant of decomposition, <jats:italic>k<jats:sub>d</jats:sub></jats:italic>, of azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) used to initiate the copolymerization was investigated. Then, the reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, of the monomers (HEMA and EGDMA), and the termination rate constant, <jats:italic>k<jats:sub>t</jats:sub></jats:italic>, were determined. Rate constants were obtained by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) experiments. The decomposition rate constant of AIBN follows an Arrhenius law in the temperature range 320–400 K. Copolymerizations were carried out in the pans of the DSC apparatus at 353 K. The reactivity ratios, determined after analysis of the mixture composition by gas chromatography, exploitation of the data using the Meyer and Lowry equation, and a numerical method, were found equal to <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.811 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 6.548. Also from the reaction rate obtained by DSC, the dependence of the termination rate constant with conversion and temperature has been established. © 2001 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 80: 1220–1228, 2001</jats:p>

Title: Effect of temperature on the monomer reactivity ratios of 2‐Hydroxypropyl methacrylate with ethyl‐ and butyl‐acrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>2‐Hydroxypropyl methacrylate has been copolymerized with ethyl acrylate and n‐butyl acrylate in bulk at temperatures between 60 and 100°C using benzoyl peroxide as initiator. The compositions of copolymers have been analyzed by hydroxyl determination; the reactivity ratios have been calculated by Kelen‐Tüdös method. Arrhenius parameters have been derived. The intrinsic viscosities and the thermal behaviours of the copolymers were also studied.</jats:p>

Title: Effect of temperature on the monomer reactivity ratios of 2‐Hydroxypropyl methacrylate with ethyl‐ and butyl‐acrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>2‐Hydroxypropyl methacrylate has been copolymerized with ethyl acrylate and n‐butyl acrylate in bulk at temperatures between 60 and 100°C using benzoyl peroxide as initiator. The compositions of copolymers have been analyzed by hydroxyl determination; the reactivity ratios have been calculated by Kelen‐Tüdös method. Arrhenius parameters have been derived. The intrinsic viscosities and the thermal behaviours of the copolymers were also studied.</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis and Characterization of New Copolymer Based Cinnamyl Methacrylate Monomer: Determination of Monomer Reactivity Ratio and Statistical Sequence

Title: Comparative recalculation of the monomer reactivity ratios in copolymerization for styrene and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios (MMRs) in radical copolymerization for styrene and methyl methacrylate were recalculated by five different methods using literature copolymerization data. The use of approximate 95% confidence limits and their visual inspection helps to separate possibly biased copolymer composition data. The recalculated mean MRR values were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> (styrene) = 0.501 ± 0.031 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.472 ± 0.031. The results of the linear least‐squares calculation procedures seldom approach the quality of the nonlinear least‐squares analysis according to the method of Tidwell and Mortimer.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetic and ESR studies on radical polymerization. ESR and kinetic evidences for the penultimate effect in the radical‐initiated copolymerization of N‐cyclohexylmaleimide and bis(2‐ethylhexyl) itaconate in benzene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐cyclohexylmaleimide (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and bis(2‐ethylhexyl) itaconate (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>) (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) with dimethyl 2,2′‐azoisobutyrate (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>) as an initiator was carried out at 50°C in benzene. Monomer reactivity ratios were estimated as <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,34 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,38. The copolymerization rate (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) and the molecular weight of the resulting copolymer increased with increasing concentration of <jats:bold>1</jats:bold> when the total concentration of comonomers was fixed at 1,00 mol. L<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> was proportional to [<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>]<jats:sup>0,5</jats:sup>, indicating a usual bimolecular termination in the copolymerization. An electron spin resonance (ESR) spectrum of the propagating polymer radicals was observable in the actual copolymerization system at 50°C. The spectrum of the copolymerization system is inexplicable in terms of any superposition of spectra observed in the corresponding homopolymerization systems, revealing that some penultimate monomeric unit causes a change in the ESR spectrum, that is, the structure of propagating polymer radical. The apparent rate constant of propagation (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) and termination (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub>) were estimated by ESR. The <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> values (1,5–50 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>) are fairly higher than those estimated on the basis of the terminal model, affording another piece of evidence for the penultimate effect. The <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub> value (1,8–5,4·10<jats:sup>3</jats:sup> L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>) shows a behaviour similar to that of the intrinsic viscosity of the resulting copolymer on varying the monomer feed composition, which seems to reflect diffusion‐control of termination reactions.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetic and ESR studies on radical polymerization. ESR and kinetic evidences for the penultimate effect in the radical‐initiated copolymerization of N‐cyclohexylmaleimide and bis(2‐ethylhexyl) itaconate in benzene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐cyclohexylmaleimide (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and bis(2‐ethylhexyl) itaconate (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>) (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) with dimethyl 2,2′‐azoisobutyrate (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>) as an initiator was carried out at 50°C in benzene. Monomer reactivity ratios were estimated as <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,34 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,38. The copolymerization rate (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) and the molecular weight of the resulting copolymer increased with increasing concentration of <jats:bold>1</jats:bold> when the total concentration of comonomers was fixed at 1,00 mol. L<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> was proportional to [<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>]<jats:sup>0,5</jats:sup>, indicating a usual bimolecular termination in the copolymerization. An electron spin resonance (ESR) spectrum of the propagating polymer radicals was observable in the actual copolymerization system at 50°C. The spectrum of the copolymerization system is inexplicable in terms of any superposition of spectra observed in the corresponding homopolymerization systems, revealing that some penultimate monomeric unit causes a change in the ESR spectrum, that is, the structure of propagating polymer radical. The apparent rate constant of propagation (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) and termination (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub>) were estimated by ESR. The <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> values (1,5–50 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>) are fairly higher than those estimated on the basis of the terminal model, affording another piece of evidence for the penultimate effect. The <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub> value (1,8–5,4·10<jats:sup>3</jats:sup> L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>) shows a behaviour similar to that of the intrinsic viscosity of the resulting copolymer on varying the monomer feed composition, which seems to reflect diffusion‐control of termination reactions.</jats:p>

Title: Free radical solution copolymerization of glycidyl methacrylate with n‐vinyl pyrrolidinone
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of glycidyl methacrylate (monomer 1) with <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl pyrrolidinone (monomer 2) were prepared at 70°C in low yield by free radical initiated solution polymerizations in ethyl acetate, 1,4‐dioxane and mixtures of the two solvents. Copolymer compositions were determined by proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. Monomer reactivity ratios were then derived using the method of Kelen & Tudos. The magnitude of r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> was relatively unaffected by solvent composition, and ranged from 4.32 to 4.53 in a random fashion. In contrast, values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> showed a greater relative (but still random) spread from 0.0075 to 0.0147. Copolymers prepared by batch polymerization are selectively enriched with GMA monomer.</jats:p>

Title: Solvent effects on radical polymerization of cyclododecyl acrylate, 2. Copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerization of cyclododecyl acrylate (CDA) with styrene (St) or acrylonitrile (AN) was studied in bulk, benzene, tetrahydrofuran, or dioxane at 60°C, and was compared with that of cyclohexyl acrylate (CHA).</jats:p><jats:p>In the copolymerization with St, the change in the ester groups or the used solvents influenced the reactivity of both acrylates in the same manner as their homopolymerization rates. Approximately, CDA and CHA behaved like methyl methacrylate in the copolymerization with St.</jats:p><jats:p>Contrary, in the cases of copolymerization of CDA with AN, peculiar results were obtained and interpreted in terms of characteristic association states of the monomers in the solutions. In benzene solution both the monomer reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, are larger than unity (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = AN, M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = CDA; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1,7, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2,0).</jats:p>

Title: Solvent effect on the methacrylic acid‐methyl methacrylate radical copolymerization. Analytical estimation by linear and nonlinear solvation energy relationships
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The calculated methacrylic acid‐methyl methacrylate monomer reactivity ratios in toluene (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 1,06 ± 0,02; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 0,10 ± 0,01), isopropyl alcohol (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0,33 ± 0,02; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 0,78 ± 0,03), acetone (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0,63 ± 0,02; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 0,31 ± 0,02) and acetonitrile (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0,46 ± 0,03; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 0,27 ± 0,03) depend strongly on the polarity, proton donor and proton acceptor ability of the solvent. It is proved that the solvent influence on the logarithm of the relative comonomer reactivities is expressed much better by the linear relationships of the solvatochromic polarity, proton donor and proton acceptor indexes than by the dependences reflecting these effects individually. The possibility of a statistically confident description of the complex solvent influence on the comonomer reactivities by quadratic solvatochromic relationships taking into account the interdependence of solvent effects is shown for the first time.</jats:p>

Title: Study on soapless emulsion copolymerization methyl methacrylate and n‐butyl acrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The soapless emulsion copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (MMA) and n‐butyl acrylate (n‐BuA) at four levels of monomer feed composition (<jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>10</jats:sub>) was studied. Conversion (<jats:italic>X</jats:italic>), average particle diameter (<jats:italic>D</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>), molecular weight distribution (<jats:italic>MWD</jats:italic>), surface charge density, and glass transition temperature (<jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>) of the copolymer as a function of reaction time (<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>) were measured. The copolymers obtained even at low conversion, except for the run of (<jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>10</jats:sub>) = 90 wt. percent MMA, exhibit two <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>s in their DSC thermograms. Phase separation is found to occur in the latex particles during polymerization. The heterogeneous distribution of monomers in particles, in which a relatively rich MMA region exists in the shell and a relatively rich n‐BuA region exists in the core of the particles, is assumed to arise from phase separation. The average copolymer composition and the fraction of the two domains are estimated. The polymerizatrion course and particle size growth follow the linear <jats:italic>X</jats:italic> vs. <jats:italic>t</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup> and <jats:italic>D</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub><jats:sup>3/2</jats:sup> vs. <jats:italic>t</jats:italic> relationships, respectively. Although the coagulation of particles happens after around 30 percent conversion, the polymerization behaviors, except for increasing rates, are not affected.</jats:p>

Title: Radical copolymerization of 2-acetoxyacrylates with nitrile monomers and properties of the copolymers
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization behavior of 2‐vinylbenzofuran: Copolymers of ethyl acrylate, n‐butyl acrylate, and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity of 2‐vinylbenzofuran in copolymerization reactions with <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate, ethyl acrylate, and methyl methacrylate was investigated. The vinylbenzofuran was found to be a very reactive monomer with the growing chain preferring to react with this monomer no matter what its terminus. Reactivity ratios were calculated using a nonlinear least squares error‐in‐variables method, which gives more reliable values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization behavior of 2‐vinylbenzofuran: Copolymers of ethyl acrylate, n‐butyl acrylate, and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity of 2‐vinylbenzofuran in copolymerization reactions with <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate, ethyl acrylate, and methyl methacrylate was investigated. The vinylbenzofuran was found to be a very reactive monomer with the growing chain preferring to react with this monomer no matter what its terminus. Reactivity ratios were calculated using a nonlinear least squares error‐in‐variables method, which gives more reliable values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetics and Modeling of Aqueous Phase Radical Homopolymerization of 3-(Methacryloylaminopropyl)trimethylammonium Chloride and its Copolymerization with Acrylic Acid
Abstract: <jats:p>The radical homopolymerization kinetics of 3-(methacryloylaminopropyl) trimethylammonium chloride (MAPTAC) and its batch copolymerization with nonionized acrylic acid (AA) in aqueous solution are investigated and modeled. The drift in monomer composition is measured during copolymerization by in situ NMR over a range of initial AA molar fractions and monomer weight fractions up to 0.35 at 50 °C. The copolymer becomes enriched in MAPTAC for monomer mixtures containing up to 60 mol% MAPTAC, but is enriched in AA for MAPTAC-rich mixtures; this azeotropic behavior is dependent on initial monomer content, as electrostatic interactions from the cationic charges influence the system reactivity ratios. Models for MAPTAC homopolymerization and AA-MAPTAC copolymerization are developed to represent the rates of monomer conversion and comonomer composition drifts over the complete range of experimental conditions.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of polar vinyl monomers with butadiene in the presence of Lewis acids
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of acrylonitrile (AN), methacrylonitrile (MAN), methyl acrylate (MA), and methyl methacrylate (MMA) with butadiene (BD) in the presence of ethylaluminium dichloride, zinc chloride, and stannic chloride was investigated. The reactivity of polar monomers in the copolymerization was found to decrease in the following order: AN>MAN>MMA>MA. It was also found that AN and MAN form with BD copolymers of essentially 1:1 composition; MMA, and particularly MA were found, however, to form with BD copolymers of a composition different from 1:1.</jats:p><jats:p>In competition with the copolymerization, a Diels‐Alder reaction was shown to occur in the investigated systems. The reactivity of polar monomers in the Diels‐Alder reaction was found to increase in the following order: MAN<AN<MMA<MA. In the presence of aluminium bromide and of antimony chloride these monomers were found to produce with BD the corresponding Diels‐Alder adducts but not the copolymers.</jats:p><jats:p>The obtained results are discussed in terms of the electron‐accepting properties of polar vinyl monomers and of the stability of transient charge‐transfer complexes between the monomers involved in the copolymerization and the Diels‐Alder reaction.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of methylmethacrylate with styrene using triphenylbismuthoniumylide as radical initiator
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Bismuthoniumylide‐initiated radical copolymerization of methylmethacrylate with styrene at 60 ± 0.2°C using dioxane as an inert solvent, follows ideal kinetics <jats:italic>(R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> ∝ [ylide]<jats:sup>0.5</jats:sup> [MMA]<jats:sup>1.0</jats:sup> [sty]<jats:sup>1.0</jats:sup>), and yields alternating copolymer as evident from NMR spectroscopy. The values of reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>1</jats:italic></jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>2</jats:italic></jats:sub><jats:italic>,</jats:italic> calculated from Finemann–Ross method are 0.48 and 0.45, respectively. The system follows ternary molecular complex mechanism. The radical mode of polymerization has been confirmed by ESR spectroscopy and the effect of hydroquinone. The value of activation energy and <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-1.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:00218995:media:APP1393:tex2gif-stack-1" />/k<jats:sub>t</jats:sub> are 65.0 KJ mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> and 2.5 × 10<jats:sup>−5</jats:sup> l mole<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, respectively. © 2001 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 80: 2774–2781, 2001</jats:p>

Title: A new improved linear graphical method for determing copolymerization reactivity ratios

Title: Reactivity Ratios and Mechanistic Insight for Anionic Ring-Opening Copolymerization of Epoxides
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Influence of aggregate formation in the copolymerization of ethyl α‐hydroxymethylacrylate with methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Ethyl α‐hydroxymethylacrylate was homopolymerized and copolymerized with methyl methacrylate in chlorobenzene and 1,4‐dioxane solutions at 50 °C with 1.5 × 10<jats:sup>−2</jats:sup> mol/L 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile as an initiator and a global monomer concentration of 3.0 mol/L. The experiments showed differences in the calculated values of the monomer reactivity ratios in both solvents. The kinetic behavior was analyzed in terms of the implicit penultimate effect and the radical reactivity ratios. All the parameters were examined with respect to the aggregation ability of the ethyl α‐hydroxymethylacrylate monomer. © 2005 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 43: 4187–4195, 2005</jats:p>

Title: Solvent effect on the free‐radical copolymerization of 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate with t‐butyl acrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free‐radical copolymerization of 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate with <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate was carried out at 50 °C in bulk and in 3 mol · L<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> 1,4‐dioxane and <jats:italic>N,N</jats:italic>′‐dimethylformamide solutions. Differences between the apparent reactivity ratios determined in this work indicated a noticeable solvent effect. This is explained with a qualitative bootstrap effect. © 2001 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 39: 2043–2048, 2001</jats:p>

Title: Radical‐initiated homopolymerization and copolymerization of ethyl α‐hydroxymethylacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Ethyl α‐hydroxymethylacrylate (EHMA) was synthesized and homopolymerized in bulk and in solution. The poly(EHMA) is readily soluble in alcohol, acetone, tetrahydrofuran, and methylene chloride at room temperature. Intramolecular lactone formation occurred when poly(EHMA) was heated to 180–230°C. The kinetics of EHMA homopolymerization was investigated in ethyl acetate, using α,α′‐azobisisobutylonitrile as an initiator. The rate of polymerization <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> was expressed by <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>[AIBN]<jats:sup>0.50</jats:sup>[EHMA]<jats:sup>1.4</jats:sup> and the overall activation energy was calculated as 71.9 kJ/mol. Kinetic constants for EHMA polymerization were obtained as follows: <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-1.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:0887624X:media:POLA080270301:tex2gif-stack-1" /> = 0.17L<jats:sup>0.9</jats:sup>mol<jats:sup>−0.9</jats:sup>s<jats:sup>−0.5</jats:sup>; 2<jats:italic>fk</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>d</jats:italic></jats:sub> = 1.5 × 10<jats:sup>−5</jats:sup> s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. The relative reactivity ratios of EHMA(M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) copolymerization with styrene (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.472, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.564) in ethyl acetate were obtained. Applying the <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic> scheme led to <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.84 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.35 for EHMA.</jats:p>

Title: Charge transfer copolymerization and properties of isopropyl methacrylate with acrylonitrile and methacrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Isopropyl methacrylate (IPMA) with Acrylonitrile (AN) and Methacrylonitrile (MAN) copolymers of different copositions were prepared at 60°C and 80°C, respectively, using a mixture of <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐Butylamine (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>BA) and carbon tetrachloride (CCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>) in dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO) as a charge transfer (CT) initiator. The percentage composition of the copolymers was established by elemental analysis. The copolymerization reactivity ratios were computed by the Kelen–Tudos method. In both the systems, IPMA was found to be more reactive; the copolymers sequence was random in nature. The copolymers were characterized by IR, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR, <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR spectroscopy and intrinsic viscosity measurements in dimethyl formamide (DMF) at 30±0.1°C. The thermal behavior of the AN‐IPMA copolymers was studied by thermogravimetry (TG) in air. The thermal stability increased, with increasing AN content in the copolymer chain. The solubility parameter of AN‐IPMA copolymer was evaluated by studying the intrinsic viscosity in different solvents. The solubility parameter of the copolymer was found to be 9.7 (cal/cc)<jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup>.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of cyclohexene-3-yl methyl methacrylate with styrene: synthesis, characterization, monomer reactivity ratios, and thermal properties

Title: A Brief Survey of Methods of Calculating Monomer Reactivity Ratios

Title: Kinetics of free‐radical copolymerization of α‐methylstyrene and styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free‐radical copolymerization of α‐methylstyrene and styrene has been studied in toluene and dimethyl phthalate solutions at 60°C. Gas chromatography was used to monitor the rate of consumption of monomers. For styrene alone, the measured rate of polymerization <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> and <jats:italic>M̄</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>n</jats:italic></jats:sub> of the polymer coincided with values expected from previous studies by other workers. Solution viscosity η affected <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> and <jats:italic>M̄</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>n</jats:italic></jats:sub> of styrene homopolymers and copolymers as expected on the basis of an inverse proportionality between η<jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup> and termination rate. The rate of initiation by azobisisobutyronitrile appears to be independent of monomer feed composition in this system. Molecular weights of copolymers can be accounted for by considering combinative termination only. The effects of radical chain transfer are not significant.</jats:p><jats:p>A theory is proposed in which the rate of termination of copolymer radicals is derived statistically from an ideal free‐radical polymerization model. This simple theory accounts quantitatively for <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> and <jats:italic>M̄</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>n</jats:italic></jats:sub> data reported here and for the results of other workers who have favored more complicated reaction models because of the apparent failure of simple copolymer reactivity ratios to predict polymer composition. This deficiency results from systematic losses of low molecular weight copolymer species in some analyses. Copolymer reactivity ratios derived with the assumption of a simple copolymer model and based on rates of monomer loss can be used to predict <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> values measured in other laboratories without necessity for consideration of depropagation or penultimate unit effects. The 60°C rate constants for propagation and termination in styrene homopolymerization were taken to be 176 and 2.7 × 10<jats:sup>7</jats:sup> mole/l.‐sec, respectively. The corresponding figures for α‐methylstyrene are 26 and 8.1 × 10<jats:sup>8</jats:sup> mole/l.‐sec. These constants account for the sluggish copolymerization behavior of the latter monomer and the low molecular weights of its copolymers. The simple reaction scheme proposed here suggests that high molecular weight styrene–α‐methylstyrene copolymers can be produced at reasonable rates at 60°C by emulsion polymerization. This is shown to be the case.</jats:p>

Title: Radical‐initiated homo‐ and copolymerization of α‐methylene‐γ‐butyrolactone
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The kinetics of α‐methylene‐γ‐butyrolactone (α‐MBL) homopolymerization was investigated in <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide (DMF) with azobis(isobutyronitrile) as initiator. The rate of polymerization (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) was expresed by <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>[AIBN]<jats:sup>0.54</jats:sup>[α‐MBL]<jats:sup>1.1</jats:sup> and the overall activation energy was calculated as 76.1 kJ/mol. Kinetic constants for α‐MBL polymerization were obtained as follows: <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub><jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup> = 0.161 L<jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup> mol<jats:sup>−1/2</jats:sup>·s<jats:sup>−1/2</jats:sup>; 2<jats:italic>fk</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>d</jats:italic></jats:sub> = 2.18 × 10<jats:sup>−5</jats:sup> s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. The relative reactivity ratios of α‐MBL(M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) copolymerization with styrene (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.14, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.87) were obtained. Applying the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>–<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> scheme led to <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 2.2 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.65. These <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for α‐MBL are higher than those for MMA</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of methacrylic acid esters with methacrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of methacrylonitrile with styrene, methacrylic acid, and eleven alkyl methacrylates have been determined and the Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:bold>e</jats:bold> values calculated. Monomer reactivity in these systems is principally a function of resonance stabilization (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>), polar factors (<jats:italic>e</jats:italic>) playing a relatively minor role. With the exception of the stearyl ester, the changes in the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values which occur on ascending the homologous series can be accounted for qualitatively in terms of the expected relative electronic displacements and of the steric effects caused by the various alkyl groups. Some correlation between monomer reactivity and the depolymerizability of the corresponding polymer has been noted.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of acryloyl chloride with 2‐hydroxypropyl methacrylate
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of N-[3-dialkylaminopropyl]methacrylamides with acrylic amides and esters in organic solvents
Abstract: <jats:p>The radical copolymerization of N-[3-(dialkylamino)-propyl]methacrylamides with a number of (meth)acrylic amides and esters in organic solvents over a wide range of molar ratios has been studied. Co-polymerisation constants for five polymerisation systems in 1,4-dioxane and toluene have been determined by the Feinman and Ross method. The influence of the solvent on the kinetics of the copolymerization of the studied monomers was found, which manifests itself in a change of the reactivity ratios of the monomers upon varying the polarity of the medium. For the obtained polymers, the presence of thermosensitive properties in aqueous solutions and the effect of the concentration and composition of copolymers on their solubility in water were shown.</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerization of methylmethacrylate and maleic anhydride
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Reactivity ratios for acrylic acid–methyl acrylate copolymerization in 1,4‐dioxane
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We report values of reactivity ratios for the copolymerization in 1,4‐dioxane of acrylic acid (AA) and methyl acrylate (MA), measured as part of work on ion‐binding to polyelectrolytes at different charge densities. Ryabov et al.<jats:sup>1</jats:sup> have shown the reactivity ratios for this and similar systems to depend on the nature and amount of the solvent used.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of methacrylic acid esters with methacrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of methacrylonitrile with styrene, methacrylic acid, and eleven alkyl methacrylates have been determined and the Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:bold>e</jats:bold> values calculated. Monomer reactivity in these systems is principally a function of resonance stabilization (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>), polar factors (<jats:italic>e</jats:italic>) playing a relatively minor role. With the exception of the stearyl ester, the changes in the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values which occur on ascending the homologous series can be accounted for qualitatively in terms of the expected relative electronic displacements and of the steric effects caused by the various alkyl groups. Some correlation between monomer reactivity and the depolymerizability of the corresponding polymer has been noted.</jats:p>

Title: Effect of pH on the reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of acrylic acid and acrylamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The content of acrylic acid and acrylamide in their copolymers can be controlled by changing pH. The reactivity ratio of acrylic acid decreases with increasing pH, while the reactivity ratio of acrylamide increases with increasing pH. At low pH values, acrylamide is present in its protonated form which causes its reactivity to be low whereas at high pH values the reactivity of acrylic acid is decreased owing to its dissociation. When the monomer and radical approach each other, the acrylate anion becomes the least reactive species because of its symmetrical charge distribution, like charge repulsion and barium ion screening effect. HMO calculations were performed for models of all monomers and polymer radicals involved in copolymerizations. The experimental results concerning the reactivity of acrylic acid and acrylamide in copolymerization and the observed reactivity ratios were discussed on the basis of HMO calculations and resonance and Coulomb electrostatic effects. The observed reactivity ratios were correlated with the calculated differences in resonance energies computed for the models of transition states involved in copolymerizations.</jats:p>

Title: Effect of pH on the reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of acrylic acid and acrylamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The content of acrylic acid and acrylamide in their copolymers can be controlled by changing pH. The reactivity ratio of acrylic acid decreases with increasing pH, while the reactivity ratio of acrylamide increases with increasing pH. At low pH values, acrylamide is present in its protonated form which causes its reactivity to be low whereas at high pH values the reactivity of acrylic acid is decreased owing to its dissociation. When the monomer and radical approach each other, the acrylate anion becomes the least reactive species because of its symmetrical charge distribution, like charge repulsion and barium ion screening effect. HMO calculations were performed for models of all monomers and polymer radicals involved in copolymerizations. The experimental results concerning the reactivity of acrylic acid and acrylamide in copolymerization and the observed reactivity ratios were discussed on the basis of HMO calculations and resonance and Coulomb electrostatic effects. The observed reactivity ratios were correlated with the calculated differences in resonance energies computed for the models of transition states involved in copolymerizations.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of n-butyl acrylate/methyl methacrylate in xylene solvent
Abstract:
<jats:p>Introduction: Copolymers are being used in a variety of fields because of their diversity and since any change could result in significant modifications. The butyl acrylate/methyl methacrylate copolymer is an extensively used polymer system with many advantages. This study aims to analyze some changes in copolymerization, from using different time or temperature of synthesis, in order to find an optimal process that can be applied in Vietnam.
Methods: Copolymerization of butyl acrylate/methyl methacrylate copolymer with different butyl acrylate/methyl methacrylate monomer ratios was done using Xylene solvent. Copolymer compositions were determined from the Proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectra and Gel permeation chromatography.
Results: The experimental results indicate that the copolymer was successfully synthesized. The highest molecular weight was 15,591 g/mol, with the lowest dispersity of 1.53 at 100 oC after 6 hours of copolymerization.
 </jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of bromophenylmaleimide with ethyl or butyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐Bromophenylmaleimide (BrPMI) does not polymerize in solution by conventional free radical mechanism. However, it readily polymerized in bulk when mixed with a free radical initiator and heated in a microwave oven for 7–8 min. Copolymerization of ethyl methacrylate or butyl methacrylate with BrPMI was conducted in dioxane. The copolymers were characterized by IR and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectroscopy and gel permeation chromatography. The monomer reactivity ratios were calculated by a non‐linear least‐square analysis. Thermal analysis indicated a great improvement in thermal stability of the copolymers compared with the methacrylate homopolymers. BrPMI was also polymerized in bulk in the DSC pan, which allowed the calculation of the activation energy of its polymerization. Copyright © 2003 Society of Chemical Industry</jats:p>

Title: Terminal and Penultimate Reactivity Ratios in the Styrene-Acrylonitrile Free-Radical Copolymerization System in Bulk
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Preferential sorption of monomers and molecular weight effects in radical copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Specific thermodynamic properties of monomer mixtures as a solvent for copolymers lead to preferential sorption of one of the monomers by the polymer coils and preferential solvation of growing chains. The dependence of the preferential sorption coefficient upon the molecular weight of the copolymers results in the dependence of copolymer composition and monomer reactivity ratios upon the molecular weight of the copolymers and in gradient chemical heterogeneity of the copolymers. “Non‐classical” copolymerizations can be represented by both terminal and penultimate models.</jats:p>

Title: Cyclohexyl Methacrylate with Tetra (Ethylene Glycol) Dimethacrylate in Tertahydrofuran Radical Copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:p>Free-radical copolymerization of cyclohexyl methacrylate (CHMA) and tetra (ethylene glycol) dimethacrylate  (TtEGDMA)  were carried out at 60 °C in tetrahydrofuran solution in presence of 2,2-azobisisobutyronitrile. The random copolymers were prepared with nominal crosslinking ratios, X of 1, 5 and 10% mol TtEGDMA / mol CHMA. The copolymers were characterized by 13C NMR spectroscopy. The copolymers was characterized by 13C RMN analysis and determined the copolymers composition. The monomer reactivity ratios r1 (TtEGDMA) and r2  (CHMA) were determined with the linearized copolymerization equations of the Fineman–Ross methods (r1 = 1.77 and r2 = 0.48) and  Kelen–Tüdös (r1 = 1.81 and r2 = 0.46). Parameters of Alfrey-Price Q1 = - 1.10 (specific activity) and e1= - 0.64 (polarity) for TtEGDMA.</jats:p>

Title: Solvent Effect on 3-Methylstyrene Radical Copolymerization with Methacrylic Acid and Methyl Methacrylate
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of 2-[3-(2H-Benzotriazol-2-yl)-4-hydroxyphenyl]ethyl Methacrylate with Styrene
Abstract: <jats:p>Radical copolymerization of 2-[3-(2<jats:italic>H</jats:italic>-benzotriazol-2-yl)-4-hydroxyphenyl]ethyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with styrene (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) at 70 °C in 1,4-dioxane was investigated and the reactivity ratios were determined. The copolymerization was carried out as batch copolymerization to a low conversion or as copolymerization with a continuous addition of monomers at higher instantaneous conversion. The monomer reactivity ratios of the copolymerizable UV stabilizer 2-[3-(2<jats:italic>H</jats:italic>-benzotriazol-2-yl)-4-hydroxyphenyl]ethyl methacrylate with styrene were determined using the Finemann-Ross plot for both copolymeration techniques. The estimated reactivity ratios were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.588 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.6 for the technique of continuous addition of monomers and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.462 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.476 and for the batch experiment. The copolymerization exhibited an azeotrope at <jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.507, thus a copolymer with microstructure close to the alternating one was formed at this ratio of comonomers. </jats:p>

Title: Determination of the reactivity parameters for the copolymerization of butyl acrylate with vinyl acetate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The composition of vinyl acetate–butyl acrylate copolymers obtained with batch emulsion polymerization have been studied by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR. Using the integrated copolymerization Meyer–Lowry equation, the apparent reactivity ratios of the two monomers were calculated as 10.67 for <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, the reactivity ratio of butyl acrylate (BA), and 0.024 for <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, the reactivity ratio of vinyl acetate (VAC). These results were compared with those obtained by other methods.</jats:p>

Title: Effect of medium pH on the reactivity ratios in acrylamide acrylic acid copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization reactivity ratios of acrylic acid and acrylamide are found at pH 5 and pH 2. Automatic continuous online monitoring of polymerization reactions (ACOMP) has been used for the first time to monitor the synthesis of polyelectrolytic copolymers. The composition drift during the reactions revealed that at pH 5, the acrylamide participates more in the copolymer, and at pH 2, the acrylic acid incorporates in the system at a higher ratio. The copolymerization data were analyzed by a recent error in variables (EVM) type calculation method developed for obtaining the reactivity ratios by on‐line monitoring and gave at pH 5 reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>Aam</jats:sub> = 1.88 ± 0.17, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>Aac</jats:sub> = 0.80 ± 0.07 and at pH 2 <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>Aam</jats:sub> = 0.16 ± 0.04, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>Aac</jats:sub> = 0.88 ± 0.08. The results show that the reactivity ratios depend strongly on the pH of the medium. The effect of polyelectrolytic interactions on the reactivity ratios is discussed in detail. © 2006 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 103: 968–974, 2007</jats:p>

Title: The influence of molecular interaction on polymerization, 9. Copolymerization of 2‐naphthyl methacrylate with acrylonitrile
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of 2‐naphthyl methacrylate (2‐NM) with acrylonitrile (AN) initiated by 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile (AIBN) was carried out in solvents with different dielectric constants. The relative reactivity ratios of the monomers determined by the Fineman‐Ross method in the solvents used are as follows:
<jats:list list-type="simple">
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in chloroform: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2‐NM</jats:sub> = 0,96 ± 0,05; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0,00 ± 0,02</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in benzene: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2‐NM</jats:sub> = 0,84 ± 0,09; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0,01 ± 0,04</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in acetone: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2‐NM</jats:sub> = 0,52 ± 0,09; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0,00 ± 0,02</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in acetonitrile: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2‐NM</jats:sub> = 0,51 ± 0,06; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0,00 ± 0,03</jats:p></jats:list-item>
</jats:list></jats:p><jats:p>The capability of the monomers to form donor‐acceptor associates was shown by means of <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectroscopy. The observed interactions between the monomer molecules on one side and between the molecules of the monomers and the solvent on the other side were used to explain the changes in the reactivity ratios of both monomers obtained in different solvents.</jats:p>

Title: The influence of molecular interaction on polymerization, 9. Copolymerization of 2‐naphthyl methacrylate with acrylonitrile
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of 2‐naphthyl methacrylate (2‐NM) with acrylonitrile (AN) initiated by 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile (AIBN) was carried out in solvents with different dielectric constants. The relative reactivity ratios of the monomers determined by the Fineman‐Ross method in the solvents used are as follows:
<jats:list list-type="simple">
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in chloroform: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2‐NM</jats:sub> = 0,96 ± 0,05; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0,00 ± 0,02</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in benzene: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2‐NM</jats:sub> = 0,84 ± 0,09; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0,01 ± 0,04</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in acetone: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2‐NM</jats:sub> = 0,52 ± 0,09; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0,00 ± 0,02</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>in acetonitrile: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2‐NM</jats:sub> = 0,51 ± 0,06; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0,00 ± 0,03</jats:p></jats:list-item>
</jats:list></jats:p><jats:p>The capability of the monomers to form donor‐acceptor associates was shown by means of <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectroscopy. The observed interactions between the monomer molecules on one side and between the molecules of the monomers and the solvent on the other side were used to explain the changes in the reactivity ratios of both monomers obtained in different solvents.</jats:p>

Title: Estimation of relative reactivity ratios in radical alternating copolymerization by means of terpolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We studied the estimation of relative reactivity ratios of the alternating copolymerization by means of terpolymerization technique either in the free propagating mechanism or in the complex mechanism. Ter‐systems studied were 2‐chloroethyl vinyl ether/fumaronitrile/maleic anhydride as one donor/two acceptor monomer system, and maleic anhydride/2‐chloroethyl vinyl ether/<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐dioxene as one acceptor/two donor monomer system. All these monomers have no radical homopolymerizability.</jats:p><jats:p>It was found that these ter‐systems coincide with the theoretical treatments and give the relative reactivity ratios in the former tersystem, k<jats:sub>12</jats:sub>/k<jats:sub>13</jats:sub> is 2.73 by the treatment of the free propagating mechanism and r<jats:sub>I</jats:sub>(K<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>/K<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) is 2.5 ± 0.2 and is 0.2 ± 0.2 by the treatment of the complex mechanism and in the latter tersystem, r<jats:sub>II</jats:sub>(K<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>/K<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) is 2.23 by the treatment of the free propagating mechanism and r<jats:sub>I</jats:sub>(K<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>/K<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) is 2.23 and r<jats:sub>II</jats:sub>(K<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>/K<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) is 0.45 by the treatment of the complex mechanism.</jats:p><jats:p>Therefore we have concluded that the terpolymerization technique is useful for the measurement of the relative reactivity of the alternating copolymerization.</jats:p>

Title: Nitroxide‐mediated radical copolymerization of methyl methacrylate controlled with a minimal amount of 9‐(4‐vinylbenzyl)‐9H‐carbazole
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The controlled nitroxide‐mediated homopolymerization of 9‐(4‐vinylbenzyl)‐9H‐carbazole (VBK) and the copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (MMA) with varying amounts of VBK were accomplished by using 10 mol % {<jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl[1‐(diethoxyphosphoryl)‐2,2‐dimethylpropyl]amino} nitroxide relative to 2‐({<jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl[1‐(diethoxyphosphoryl)‐2,2‐dimethylpropyl]amino}oxy)‐2‐methylpropionic acid (BlocBuilder™) in dimethylformamide at temperatures from 80 to 125 °C. As little as 1 mol % of VBK in the feed was required to obtain a controlled copolymerization of an MMA/VBK mixture, resulting in a linear increase in molecular weight versus conversion with a narrow molecular weight distribution (<jats:styled-content><jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>w</jats:sub></jats:styled-content>/<jats:styled-content><jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>n</jats:sub></jats:styled-content> ≈ 1.3). Preferential incorporation of VBK into the copolymer was indicated by the MMA/VBK reactivity ratios determined: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>VBK</jats:sub> = 2.7 ± 1.5 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 0.24 ± 0.14. The copolymers were found significantly “living” by performing subsequent chain extensions with a fresh batch of VBK and by <jats:sup>31</jats:sup>P NMR spectroscopy analysis. VBK was found to be an effective controlling comonomer for NMP of MMA, and such low levels of VBK comonomer ensured transparency in the final copolymer. © 2010 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem, 2011</jats:p>

Title: Styrene–maleic anhydride copolymerization through polar transition states in polar solvents
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radical copolymerization of styrene (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and maleic anhydride (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) was performed in highly polar, oxygen lone‐pair donor solvents (<jats:italic>N, N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide, <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐methylfor‐mamide) at high temperatures (135 and 145°C) and in strong π‐electron donor solvents (1,3‐dimethoxybenzene and 1,2,4‐trimethoxybenzene) at 60‐145°C. The corresponding reactivity ratios were evaluated by Fineman–Ross, Kelen Tüdos, and error‐in‐variables model (RREVM) methods. The reactivity ratios obtained (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> < 1) show that alternating copolymers were produced. These results are best explained if the copolymerizations proceed through highly polarized radical transition states rather than styrene–maleic anhydride charge‐transfer complexes. Polar solvents stabilize highly polarized radical transition states thereby promoting alternating polymerization at higher temperatures than can be observed in nonpolar solvents. Donor solvents might also stabilize the electrophilic maleic anhydride radical more than the nucleophilic styryl radical thereby tending to depress k<jats:sub>21</jats:sub> relative to k<jats:sub>12</jats:sub>. The copolymerizations were also studied in decalin (a nonpolar, nondonor solvent) at 60‐145°C. At lower temperatures alternating copolymers were combined. However, at temperatures > 120°C, random copolymers were obtained in decalin. Thus, in decalin, styrene–maleic anhydride charge‐transfer complexes are present at lower temperatures where they might play a role in alternation. In decalin the solvation of the polar transition states (relative to the macroradicals and monomers) does not favor copolymerization through such dipolar structures. Thus, at low temperatures growing chains could add to charge‐transfer complexes. However, at temperatures above 120°C the concentration of charge‐transfer complexes becomes so small that they can no longer be kinetically important contributions to the copolymerization. Thus, random copolymers with high styrene mole ratios are produced in decalin. The equilibrium constants for complex formation between maleic anhydride and both 1,3‐dimethoxybenzene and 1,2,4‐trimethoxybenzene were de‐termined in 1 : 1 (v/v) CCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>/CDCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> using a technique based on changes in the NMR chemical shifts of the maleic anhydride protons. © 1995 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Monomer reactivity ratios for the styrene‐2,5‐dichlorostyrene copolymerization
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Research in the field of terpolymers. I. Copolymerization of acrylonitrile/methaerylic acid/methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>It is known that copolymerization reactions permit the extension of the scope of monomer utilizations, and especially, the controlled modification of the physico‐chemical and mechanical properties of polymers. Many types of elastomers, plastics and synthetic fibers are synthetized at present on the basis of such a reaction.</jats:p><jats:p>In the last years the field of synthetic fibres has acquired an ever wider utilization together with other groups of spinning polymers as, for instance, the polyamides and polyesters, the acrylic and vinylic copolymers where acrylonitrile is the main component, thanks to the properties it imparts on the polymers.</jats:p><jats:p>The kinetics of the copolymerization of the ternary system acrylonitrile/methacrylic acid/methyl methacrylate is studied. The polymerization was carried out in inert medium and homogeneous phase (solvent: ethylene glycole carbonate) using lauryl peroxide as initiator.</jats:p><jats:p>The authors investigated the variation of copolymer composition as compared to the initial monomer ratios at different conversions and depending on polymerization conditions.</jats:p><jats:p>For the calculation of the composition at a high degree of conversion the monomer reactivities were determined at 70°C by using F<jats:sc>INEMAN</jats:sc>‐R<jats:sc>OSS</jats:sc>, M<jats:sc>AYO</jats:sc>‐L<jats:sc>EWIS</jats:sc>, and J<jats:sc>OSHI</jats:sc>‐K<jats:sc>APUR</jats:sc>, relations. Some discrepancies in the results obtained by each of these methods are discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Solution copolymerization of styrene and 2‐hydroxyethyl mechacrylate.
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The rate of solution copolymerization of styrene (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) was investigated by dilatometry. <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethyl formamide, toluene, isopropyl alcohol, and butyl alcohol were used as solvents. Polymerization was initiated by α,α′‐azobisisobutyronitrile at 60°C. The initial copolymerization rate increased nonlinearly with increasing 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA)/styrene ratio. The copolymerization rate was promoted by solvents containing hydroxyl groups. Two different approaches were used for the prediction of copolymerization rates. The relationships proposed for the copolymerization rates calculation involve the effects of the total monomer concentration, mole fraction of HEMA, and of the solvent type. Different reactivity ratios were found in polar and nonpolar solvents: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.53, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.59 in <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethyl formamide, isopropyl alcohol and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.50, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.65 in toluene. The usability of these reactivity ratios was confirmed by batch experiments.</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerization reactions of N‐(2‐methyl‐5‐dimethylaminophenyl)maleimide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerization of N‐(2‐methyl‐5‐dimethylaminophenyl)maleimide (I) with styrene (S), methyl methacrylate (MMA), 2‐dimethylaminoethyl methacrylate (DAMA), acrylonitrile (AN), methacrylic acid (MA), and isoprene (IP) was investigated. The reactivity ratios of pairs of monomers I ‐ S, I ‐ MMA were determined, and the Alfrey‐Price constants <jats:italic>e, Q</jats:italic> of the imide I were calculated. Along with the copolymerization of I with IP, the Diels‐Alder addition proceeding in parallel was also followed.</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis and characterization of copolymers from acrylic and methacrylic acid with 2‐methylaziridine by spontaneous copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>2‐Methylaziridine (MAz) as a nucleophilic monomer and acrylic acid (AA) and methacrylic acid (MA), respectively, as electrophilic monomers were copolymerized in the absence of initiator at various feed ratios. Copolymers were characterized by elemental analysis, FT‐IR and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopy. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined by the Fineman‐Ross and Kelen‐Tüdős methods. Values of r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were found to be less than unity for MAz‐AA, and MAz‐MA, corresponding to random copolymers with the tendency to the alternance. For all the copolymers the thermal decomposition with 10% weight loss is higher than 430 K. The reaction order for degradation of all copolymers was zero. The kinetic parameters of the decomposition were determined for all copolymers.</jats:p>

Title: Estimation of the reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of acrylic acid and acrylamide from composition–conversion measurements by an improved nonlinear least-squares method
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Free‐radical‐initiated copolymerization of 2‐(2‐naphthylamino)‐2‐oxo‐ethyl methacrylate with methyl methacrylate and styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A naphthylamino species containing the methacrylate‐based monomer 2‐(2‐naphthylamino)‐2‐oxo‐ethyl methacrylate (NphAOEMA) was synthesized by reacting 2‐chloro‐<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐2‐naphthylacetamide (NphA) with sodium methacrylate in acetonitrile. The acetamide was prepared by reacting 1‐naphthylamine, dissolved in benzene, with chloroacetylchloride. The free‐radical‐initiated copolymerization's of NphAOEMA, with methyl methacrylate (MMA) and styrene (ST), were carried out in dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) solution at 65 °C using 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as the initiator with various monomer‐to‐monomer ratios in the feed. The monomer (NphAOEMA) and copolymers were characterized from FT‐IR, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR spectral studies. The copolymer compositions were evaluated by determining the nitrogen contents in the polymers. The reactivity ratios of the monomers were determined by the application of the Fineman–Ross and Kelen–Tüdőos methods. The molecular weights (<jats:italic>M̄</jats:italic><jats:sub>w</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>M̄</jats:italic><jats:sub>n</jats:sub>) and polydispersity indices of the polymers were measured by using gel permation chromagtography. The thermal stabilities of the homo and copolymers were investigated by using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). The solubilities and inherent viscosities of the homo and copolymers were also studied. Copyright © 2004 Society of Chemical Industry</jats:p>

Title: Graft polymers with macromonomers. II. Copolymerization kinetics of methacrylate‐terminated polystyrene and predicted graft copolymer structures
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization studies of methacrylate‐terminated polystyrene macromonomers (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with several comonomers (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) verified the modified kinetic scheme and permitted prediction of graft polymer compositions and structures. Instantaneous and cumulative copolymer compositions, average graft distributions, and grafts per molecule are predicted from FORTRAN IV or BASIC programs. The <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> relative reactivity ratios determined from styrene copolymerization (0.61) or from low conversion acrylic monomer in aqueous suspension (∼0.4) had good agreement with literature values (about 0.6 and 0.4, respectively). Decreased macromonomer reactivity determined at high acrylic monomer conversions was attributed to phase separation phenomena. The Macromers also exhibited lower reactivity than predicted when copolymerized with acrylic monomers in DMSO/benzene solutions (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> ∼ 0.8).</jats:p>

Title: Monomer Reactivity Ratios for the Copolymerization of Methyl Methacrylate with Pure Meta- and Pure Para-Divinylbenzene
