Title: Alternating Copolymerization of β-Cyanoacrolein with α-Methylstyrene
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Alternating copolymer was obtained in the system of β-cyanoacrolein (CAL) and α-methyl-styrene (α-MeSt). In the presence of air copolymerization proceeds even without any radical initiator at room temperature. In the radical initiated copolymerization of α-MeSt (M1) and CAL (M2), the values of monomer reactivity ratios r1=0.033 and r2=0 were obtained. Neither the rate of copolymerization nor viscosity number of the copolymer formed were influenced by the presence of air in the reaction system. The result of copolymerization in the ternary system involving methyl acrylate (MA) could not be entirely explained by the copolymerization equation given by Alfrey and Goldfinger for the three component system. It was found that the composition of the copolymer formed changed with the solvent dilution. Formation of 1 : 1 molecular complex between the monomers was evidenced by the application of the continuous variation method to α-MeSt-CAL system. It was concluded that the molecular complex due to some donor-acceptor type interaction between CAL and α-MeSt plays an important role in the copolymerization.</jats:p>

Title: Characterization by tin‐specific size exclusion chromatography of the free radical copolymerization of tributyltin methacrylate and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of tributyltin methacrylate (TBTM) and methyl methacrylate (MMA) comprise an important class of biocidal slow‐release organometallic polymers (OMPs). Little is known of the kinetics and mechanism of copolymerization. TBTM and MMA were copolymerized in the presence of a free radical initiator (benzoyl peroxide) at 80.1°C. Aliquots, taken at preselected intervals from 0 to 1440 min, were fractionated by size exclusion chromatography (SEC) coupled with ultraviolet (UV) and tin‐specific graphite furnace atomic absorption (GFAA) detectors. A UV absorbance observed at 254 nm was associated with low‐molecular‐weight species, decreasing in concentration continuously with time of reaction. Tin‐specific GFAA indicated a decrease in low‐molecular‐weight species (ca. 350 daltons) with concurrent increases in high‐molecular‐weight species (ca. 40,000 daltons). The fraction of high molecular‐weight increased as a linear function of the logarithm of the time of reaction. SEC–UV–GFAA thus provides a tool of major importance for characterizing the time dependence and continuity of the process by which monomers of TBTM are converted to a useful bioactive slow‐release coating material.</jats:p>

Title: Glycidyl methacrylate–tert‐butyl acrylate copolymers: Synthesis, characterization, and thermal studies
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Glycidyl methacrylate was copolymerized with tert‐butyl acrylate in bulk at 60°C using benzoyl peroxide as free radical initiator. The copolymer composition was determined by chemical analysis as well as from <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR data. The monomer reactivity ratios were calculated by using the YBR method. The number average sequence length of the copolymers was determined from <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR data and compared with those obtained from reactivity ratios. The intrinsic viscosity of the copolymers was determined in DMF, and thermal stability as well as mechanism of thermal degradation of the copolymers were evaluated.</jats:p>

Title: Glycidyl methacrylate–tert‐butyl acrylate copolymers: Synthesis, characterization, and thermal studies
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Glycidyl methacrylate was copolymerized with tert‐butyl acrylate in bulk at 60°C using benzoyl peroxide as free radical initiator. The copolymer composition was determined by chemical analysis as well as from <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR data. The monomer reactivity ratios were calculated by using the YBR method. The number average sequence length of the copolymers was determined from <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR data and compared with those obtained from reactivity ratios. The intrinsic viscosity of the copolymers was determined in DMF, and thermal stability as well as mechanism of thermal degradation of the copolymers were evaluated.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of propagation and termination rate constants for some methacrylates in their radical polymerizations
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Rotating sector determinations of <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> and 2<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub> for ten methacrylates undergoing radical polymerization were carried out at 30°C. Ester groups in the monomers were: isopropyl, ethyl, β‐cyclohexylethyl, methyl, γ‐phenylpropyl, β‐phenylethyl, β‐methoxyethyl, benzyl, β‐chloroethyl, and phenyl. Values of <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> obtained were 121, 126, 1190, 141, 149, 228, 249, 1250, 254, and 411 l./mole‐sec., respectively; values of 2<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub> × 10<jats:sup>−6</jats:sup> were 4.52, 7.35, 32.8, 11.6, 0.813, 1.88, 9.30, 41.9, 6.71, and 11.9 l./mole‐sec., respectively.</jats:p><jats:p>Omitting the data for the β‐cyclohexylethyl and benzyl esters, a Taft correlation, log <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = (0.70 ± 0.18)σ* + 2.2, was established, where σ* denotes Taft's polar substitutent constants for the above‐mentioned ester groups. The steric substituent constants <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>s</jats:italic></jats:sub> were found to have no influence on <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>. Combination of <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> with <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> data from copolymerization studies with styrene or methyl methacrylate as M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> comonomer revealed that the more reactive monomer gave rise to the more reactive polymer radical. Monomer viscosities and molar volumes of the ester groups were found to correlate with 2<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub>.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of styrene and methyl methacrylate. Reactivity ratios from conversion–composition data
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A method for the determination of reactivity ratios from conversion–composition data has been outlined. The conversion–composition changes during the copolymerization of styrene (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and methyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) have been studied at 60°C. By a method of graphical intersection, the integrated form of Skeist's equation has been used to determine the reactivity ratios (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.54 ± 0.02 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.50 ± 0.06) in reasonably good agreement with values reported in the literature. The area of intersection was used as a measure of the precision of the data.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of styrene and styrene–acrylonitrile with polybutadienes
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of styrene and styrene–acrylonitrile with polybutadienes of various microstructures was studied and the reactivity ratios determined. It was shown that for the styrene/acrylonitrile/polybutadiene systems the 1,2 structure is twice as reactive as the trans and four times as reactive as the cis. Studies in the temperature range of 50–80°C reveal that the reactivity of the polybutadiene increases as the temperature rises. When styrene is the monomer the reactivity of polybutadiene and the temperature effect is less intense than when styrene–acrylonitrile is used.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of Styrene and Pentadecylphenylmethacrylate (PDPMA): Synthesis, Characterization, Thermomechanical and Adhesion Properties
Abstract: <jats:p>The copolymerization of styrene (St) with a bioderived monomer, pentadecylphenyl methacrylate (PDPMA), via atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) was studied in this work. The copolymerization reactivity ratio was calculated using the composition data obtained from 1H NMR spectroscopy, applying Kelen-Tudos and Finemann-Ross methods. The reactivity ratio of styrene (r1 = 0.93) and PDPMA (r2 = 0.05) suggested random copolymerization of the two monomers with alternation. The copolymerization conversion increased with increasing PDPMA concentration of the feed, upto 70 wt % PDPMA, but decreased thereafter. The molecular weight determined by gel permeation chromatography was lower than the theoretical values and the polydispersity increased from 1.32 to 2.19, with increasing PDPMA content in the feed. The influence of styrene content on the glass transition and thermal decomposition behavior of the copolymers was studied by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetric analysis, respectively. Morphological characterization by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) revealed a phase separated soft core-hard shell type structure. The complex viscosity and adhesion properties like peel strength and lap shear strength of the copolymer on different substrates increased with increasing styrene content.</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerization of phenyl methacrylate with methacrylic acid
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Kinetics of the free radical copolymerization of diethyl maleate with methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The kinetics of the free radical copolymerization of diethyl maleate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with methyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) was studied in bulk at 60°C with azoisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator. The reactivity ratios of the system were determined by means of <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectroscopy. The obtained values show that diethyl maleate is not only unable to homopolymerize (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> = 0) but also display a very low tendency to incorporate in the polymer chain (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> = 370) under the present conditions. Molecular weight measurements showed that a normal, although very slow growth reaction involving diethyl maleate takes place. Therefore, chain transfer could be neglected in the kinetic analysis. The dependence of the initiation rate constant on the monomer feed was analysed by means of the inhibition method. An equation for describing the observed dependence of polymerization rate on feed composition was derived taking into account the influence of solution viscosity on the termination rate constant (diffusion theory).</jats:p>

Title: Comments on the Kuo‐Chen method to determine monomer reactivity ratios in copolymerization
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Free radical copolymerization of furfuryl acrylate and 2‐hydroxyethyl‐methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of furfuryl acrylate (<jats:bold>F</jats:bold>) and 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (<jats:bold>H</jats:bold>) were prepared by free radical polymerization in DMF solution at 50°C, using 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator. The reactivity ratios of both monomers were calculated according to the general copolymerization equation using the Fineman‐Ross and Kelen‐Tüdös linearization methods, as well as the Tidwell and Mortimer nonlinear least‐squares treatment. The reactivity ratios obtained were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>F</jats:sub> = 0.93 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>H</jats:sub> = 1.42. The microstructure of copolymer chains is described on the basis of first‐order Markov statistics, and the copolymer glass transition temperatures were determined calorimetrically. The variation of <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> with the copolymer composition is discussed according to modern methods, considering the sequence distribution of monomeric units along the copolymer chains. Also the <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> of the corresponding homopolymers was determined giving the values <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>(<jats:bold>F</jats:bold>) = 321 K and <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>(<jats:bold>H</jats:bold>) = 358 K, whereas the <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> of the corresponding alternating diad has an average value of <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic>FH</jats:sub> = 326 K. © 1993 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Free radical copolymerization of furfuryl acrylate and 2‐hydroxyethyl‐methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of furfuryl acrylate (<jats:bold>F</jats:bold>) and 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (<jats:bold>H</jats:bold>) were prepared by free radical polymerization in DMF solution at 50°C, using 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator. The reactivity ratios of both monomers were calculated according to the general copolymerization equation using the Fineman‐Ross and Kelen‐Tüdös linearization methods, as well as the Tidwell and Mortimer nonlinear least‐squares treatment. The reactivity ratios obtained were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>F</jats:sub> = 0.93 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>H</jats:sub> = 1.42. The microstructure of copolymer chains is described on the basis of first‐order Markov statistics, and the copolymer glass transition temperatures were determined calorimetrically. The variation of <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> with the copolymer composition is discussed according to modern methods, considering the sequence distribution of monomeric units along the copolymer chains. Also the <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> of the corresponding homopolymers was determined giving the values <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>(<jats:bold>F</jats:bold>) = 321 K and <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>(<jats:bold>H</jats:bold>) = 358 K, whereas the <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> of the corresponding alternating diad has an average value of <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic>FH</jats:sub> = 326 K. © 1993 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Studies in copolymerization The evaluation of the kinetic coefficients for the system styrene-butyl acrylate
Abstract: <jats:p>The mechanism of the copolymerization of styrene and butyl acrylate has been investigated in mixtures of these monomers using benzoyl peroxide as initiator. The peroxide was decomposed both thermally and photochemically. Experiments on the composition of the polymer as a function of the monomer composition have given the reactivity ratios styrene radical-styrene molecule to styrene radical-butyl acrylate molecule as 0·48 and butyl acrylate radical butyl acrylate molecule to butyl acrylate radical to styrene molecule as 0·15. The kinetics of the copolymerization have been determined, and using the theory already elaborated for the treatment of such reactions, it has been shown by rate and molecular weight measurements that the styrene radicals react with the butyl acrylate radicals more quickly than the mean rate of reaction of styrene to styrene and butyl acrylate to butyl acrylate radicals. The coefficient Ø defining this increased activity is not in this case constant and rises with increasing styrene content to a value of as much as 150. The initiation mechanism is also complicated in that there is no linear relation between the rate of initiation and monomer composition; instead, the rate drops rapidly when styrene is added to the butyl acrylate.</jats:p>

Title: Monomer reactivity ratios of N‐octadecylacrylamide and N‐allylstearamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios and the corresponding copolymerization parameters for the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐octadecylacrylamide (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and several monomers in <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol at 60 ± 0.1°C. were determined and were: with acrylonitrile, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.44 ± 0.019, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.10 ± 0.035; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.60, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.20; with vinylidene chloride, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.37 ± 0.008, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.438 ± 0.008; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.65, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.08; with vinyl acetate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 6.11 ± 0.045, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.027 ± 0.009; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.72, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.12. The mean copolymerization parameters, therefore, were <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.66, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.13. The reactivity ratios and the corresponding copolymerization parameters for the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐ally lstearamide (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and several monomers, polymerized in <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol at 80 ± 0.1°C. (except for vinyl acetate, polymerized in bulk at 70 ± 0.1°C.) were determined and were: with acrylonitrile, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.118 ± 0.084, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 3.61 ± 0.087; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.058; <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.21; with vinylidene chloride, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0 ± 0.136, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 5.23 ± 0.067; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.028, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −0.80; with vinyl acetate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.0532 ± 0.012, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.740 ± 0.087; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.043, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −1.18. The mean copolymerization parameters for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐allylstearamide were, therefore, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.043, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −0.59.</jats:p>

Title: Monomer reactivity ratios of N‐octadecylacrylamide and N‐allylstearamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios and the corresponding copolymerization parameters for the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐octadecylacrylamide (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and several monomers in <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol at 60 ± 0.1°C. were determined and were: with acrylonitrile, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.44 ± 0.019, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.10 ± 0.035; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.60, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.20; with vinylidene chloride, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.37 ± 0.008, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.438 ± 0.008; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.65, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.08; with vinyl acetate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 6.11 ± 0.045, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.027 ± 0.009; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.72, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.12. The mean copolymerization parameters, therefore, were <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.66, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.13. The reactivity ratios and the corresponding copolymerization parameters for the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐ally lstearamide (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and several monomers, polymerized in <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol at 80 ± 0.1°C. (except for vinyl acetate, polymerized in bulk at 70 ± 0.1°C.) were determined and were: with acrylonitrile, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.118 ± 0.084, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 3.61 ± 0.087; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.058; <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.21; with vinylidene chloride, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0 ± 0.136, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 5.23 ± 0.067; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.028, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −0.80; with vinyl acetate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.0532 ± 0.012, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.740 ± 0.087; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.043, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −1.18. The mean copolymerization parameters for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐allylstearamide were, therefore, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.043, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −0.59.</jats:p>

Title: The mechanism of vinyl polymerization initiated by metal alkyls: Copolymerization studies
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios have been determined for the copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and acrylonitrile (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) catalyzed by alkyl derivatives of lithium, sodium, beryllium, magnesium, boron, aluminum, zinc, and cadmium. Lithium, sodium, beryllium, and magnesium alkyls gave reactivity ratios averaging <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.34, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 6.7, while alkyls of boron, aluminum, zinc, and cadmium gave <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.24, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.11. These values compare favorably with published reactivity ratios for anionic copolymerization (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.25, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 7.9) and free‐radical copolymerization (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.35, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.18). Therefore, alkyl derivatives of groups Ia and IIa metals propagate by an anionic mechanism, while those of groups IIb and IIIa do so by a free‐radical mechanism. Confirmatory experiments were run using styrene (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–acrylonitrile (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) solutions. For groups Ia and IIa alkyls the reactivity ratios averaged, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.20, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 12.5; and for Groups IIb and IIIa <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.33, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.03. The published values for free‐radical catalysts are <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.41, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.04. The formation of free radicals from the groups IIb and IIIa metal alkyls probably arises from oxidation of the metal alkyls by chance traces of oxygen.</jats:p>

Title: Using 1H‐NMR spectroscopy for the kinetic study of the in situ solution free‐radical copolymerization of styrene and ethyl acrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free‐radical copolymerization of styrene and ethyl acrylate in benzene‐<jats:italic>d</jats:italic><jats:sub>6</jats:sub> as the solvent in the presence of benzoyl peroxide as an initiator at 70°C was studied by online <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopy. The chemical composition of the copolymer at different reaction times was calculated from the conversion of the monomers to the copolymer, and then the reactivity ratios of styrene and ethyl acrylate were determined at both low and high conversions. Data for the overall monomer conversion versus the time were used to estimate the ratio <jats:italic>k<jats:sub>p</jats:sub>k<jats:sub>t</jats:sub></jats:italic><jats:sup>−0.5</jats:sup> for different compositions of the initial feed (<jats:italic>k<jats:sub>p</jats:sub></jats:italic> is the propagation rate constant, and <jats:italic>k<jats:sub>t</jats:sub></jats:italic> is the termination rate constant). <jats:italic>k<jats:sub>p</jats:sub></jats:italic><jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-1.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:00218995:media:APP26290:tex2gif-stack-1" /> increased with an increasing molar fraction of ethyl acrylate in the initial feed. The monomer mixture and copolymer compositions versus the overall monomer conversion were calculated with the data of <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectra. The incorporation of the styrene monomer into the copolymer structure was more favored than that of the ethyl acrylate monomer. Reducing the molar fraction of styrene in the initial feed intensified this. Drawing the molar fraction of styrene (or ethyl acrylate) in the copolymer chains versus that in the initial feed showed a tendency of the system toward random copolymerization. © 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci, 2007</jats:p>

Title: Formaldehyde polymers, 25. Copolymerization of 6,8‐dimethyl‐4‐oxo‐5‐chromanylmethyl acrylate with styrene, methyl methacrylate, and vinyl chloride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free radical copolymerizations of 6,8‐dimethyl‐4‐oxo‐5‐chromanylmethyl acrylate (DCA) with styrene (St), methyl methacrylate (MMA), and vinyl chloride (VC) by the solution polymerization method were studied. For copolymerization of DCA(M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with St(M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), the reactivity ratios were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>=0,32, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>=0,70; with MMA(M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) they were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>=0,43, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>=2,00; and with VC(M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) they were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>=4,00, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>=0,08. The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for DCA were 0,54 and 0,42, respectively. It was also shown that the chromanone skeleton acts as UV‐absorber, and inhibits photodegradation of the copolymers.</jats:p>

Title: Alternating copolymerization of conjugated vinyl monomers with isobutylene, styrene, and vinyl acetate in the presence of ethylaluminum dichloride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of acrylonitrile (AN), methacrylonitrile (MAN), methyl vinyl ketone (MVK), methyl acrylate (MA), and methyl methacrylate (MMA), complexed by ethylaluminum dichloride, with isobutylene (IB), styrene (St), and vinyl acetate (VA) was studied. It was found to proceed spontaneously resulting alternating copolymers. The reactivity of the polar monomers complexed by EtAlCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> in their copolymerization with St and IB was investigated and found to decrease in the following order: AN > MAN > MA > MMA and AN > MVK > MA, respectively, (MAN and MMA do not give copolymers with IB). A correlation of the copolymerization yield with the e value for the uncomplexed monomers investigated was observed.</jats:p>

Title: Study on monomer reactivity ratios of acrylonitrile/itaconic acid in aqueous deposited copolymerization system initiated by ammonium persulfate
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Controlled radical alternating copolymerization of N‐phenyl maleimide with ethyl α‐ethylacrylate by reversible addition fragmentation chain‐transfer process
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The alternating copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐phenyl maleimide (NPMI) with ethyl α‐ethylacrylate (EEA) by the reversible addition fragmentation chain‐transfer process was investigated. The monomer reactivity ratios were measured and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.19 ± 0.03 for NPMI and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.20 ± 0.04 for EEA. It was found that before about 45% of the comonomer conversion, the molecular weight of the copolymer increased with the conversion, the molecular weight distribution was rather narrow, and the molecular weight of the copolymer approached a constant value, irrespective of the length of the polymerization time. Electronic spin resonance determined that the radical signal disappeared quickly after the conversion of comonomer exceeded 45%, which may be attributed to the coupling termination of the propagating polymer chains with the EEA end with the intermediate radicals when the concentration of comonomers decreased. © 2004 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 94: 2376–2382, 2004</jats:p>

Title: A graphic method for the determination of monomer reactivity ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Bulk Free Radical Terpolymerization of Butyl Acrylate, 2-Methylene-1,3-Dioxepane and Vinyl Acetate: Terpolymer Reactivity Ratio Estimation
Abstract: <jats:p>This investigation introduces the first estimation of ternary reactivity ratios for a butyl acrylate (BA), 2-methylene-1,3-dioxepane (MDO), and vinyl acetate (VAc) system at 50 °C, with an aim to develop biodegradable pressure-sensitive adhesives (PSAs). In this study, we applied the error-in-variables model (EVM) to estimate reactivity ratios. The ternary reactivity ratios were found to be r12 = 0.417, r21 = 0.071, r13 = 4.459, r31 = 0.198, r23 = 0.260, and r32 = 55.339 (BA/MDO/VAc 1/2/3), contrasting with their binary counterparts, which are significantly different, indicating the critical need for ternary system analysis to accurately model multicomponent polymerization systems. Through the application of a recast Alfrey–Goldfinger model, this investigation predicts the terpolymer’s instantaneous and cumulative compositions at various conversion levels, based on the ternary reactivity ratios. These predictions not only provide crucial insights into the incorporation of MDO across different initial feed compositions but also offer estimates of the final terpolymer compositions and distributions, underscoring their potential in designing compostable or degradable polymers.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of N-Arylmaleimide with Vinyl Acetate—Effect of the Total Monomer Concentration on the Reactivity Ratios of the Copolymerization
Abstract: No abstract available
